case_title: MUHAMMAD SIDDIQUE QURESHI AND 3 OTHERS vs S. NASIR AHMAD SHAH (REPRESENTED BY 5 LEGAL HEIRS) AND 7 OTHERS
respondant: S. Nasir Ahmad Shah (Represented by 5 Legal Heirs)

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Siddique
allegation: Violation of Paragraph 10 of the Scheme

prosecution: Counsel for S. Nasir Ahmad Shah
defense: Counsel for Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan

complaint_summary: Dispute over the transfer and proprietary rights of agricultural land initially allotted to Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan under Martial Law Regulation No. 89/91.
investigation_summary: The case involved allegations of fraudulent land transfer, misrepresentation, and violation of legal provisions governing the transfer of government-allotted land. Multiple parties, including Muhammad Siddique and S. Nasir Ahmad Shah, claimed rights over the land based on agreements and court decrees.

findings: Transfers made without Collector's permission are void.
Ex parte civil court decree does not bind the government.
Fraud and misrepresentation invalidated proprietary rights granted to Muhammad Siddique.
directions: Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan allowed to deposit unpaid installments within two months.
Failure to deposit will result in land resumption.

Decision_or_verdict: Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan allowed to deposit unpaid installments within two months to acquire proprietary rights; failure to do so would result in land resumption.
legal_arguments: Muhammad Siddique argued that the Board of Revenue could not review its earlier orders.
S. Nasir Ahmad Shah's counsel relied on a civil court decree to claim rights.
Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan contended that his rights remained intact under the revised policy.
assets: Agricultural land in villages Kharianwala, Ammonki, Jhabbran, Dhilwan, Mukta, and Bhatti Dhilwan, Tehsil and District Sheikhupura.

witness_statement.Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan: Claimed his rights to purchase the land under the revised policy.
witness_statement.Muhammad Siddique: Defended his acquisition of proprietary rights as valid.
witness_statement.S. Nasir Ahmad Shah: Relied on a civil court decree to assert his claim.

key_issues: Applicability of civil court decrees to government-allotted land.

maxims.Fraud vitiates everything: Fraudulent actions render legal proceedings and agreements void.

legal_terms.Ex Parte Decree: A court decision made in the absence of one party.

words_and_phrases.Optee Purchaser: A person who opts to purchase government-allotted land.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around disputes over the transfer of agricultural land allotted under Martial Law Regulation No. 89/91. Fraudulent actions, misrepresentation, and improper legal procedures were central issues. The court invalidated orders favoring Muhammad Siddique and S. Nasir Ahmad Shah, affirming Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan's rights to purchase the land upon fulfilling payment obligations.

facts.surrendered_area_option: Allowed to purchase at Rs. 10 per P.I. Unit

parties: S. Nasir Ahmad Shah and others

civil_court_decree.result: Restrained Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan from encumbering or interfering with possession of land

payment_history.policy_relaxation: Allowed payment of defaulted installments by 1972-06-30

key_orders.content: Permission granted to S. Nasir Ahmad Shah to deposit unpaid installments
Permission granted to Nawabzada Asghar Ali Khan to deposit balance price
Proprietary rights granted to Muhammad Siddique
Permission extended to S. Nasir Ahmad Shah to clear dues
